subject: ES
course_name: ADV TPC: POLITICAL ECOLOGY: Art Ecologies
additional_information: Description: This class combines lectures and applied studio explorations for reflection and creative inquiry. Weâll engage in a range of both solo and collaborative creative explorations alongside written assignments. Through experimental processes and creative inquiry, students will consider the potential of art-led research and creative, ecological art practice as important to reimagining social and environmental justice.

subject: ES
course_name: ADV TPC:POLITICAL ECOLOGY: Environmental Communication for Real-World Solutions
additional_information: 5 day intensive Reading Break course. Invites students to approach critical environmental issues, and in some cases, their thesis research, from an evidence-based, solutions perspective, drawing on relevant theories from environmental communications to critique climate doomism and craft hopeful, real world engagement. Important Note: Non-standard dates apply to this section. See the âcourses and registration pageâ and select âCourses with non-standard dates and deadlinesâ section to view the 100% fee reduction, 50% fee reduction and academic drop dates for this course.

subject: ES
course_name: ADV TPC:ECOLOGICAL RESTORATN: Analyzing Data for Boreal Mammal Ecology
additional_information: Discover the ecology of the vast boreal forest and learn applied statistics to answer questions about boreal mammal ecology. The course combines ecological theory and especially new modes of statistical analysis to explore the latest techniques for studying boreal wildlife.

subject: ES
course_name: ADV TPC:ECOLOGICAL RESTORATN: Foundations of Ecology
additional_information: This is primarily a reading course where we delve deeply into some classic ecology research papers on topics including, but not limited to, the following: the niche, populations, communities, ecosystems, food webs, the rise of experimental ecology, theoretical ecology, conservation biology, meta-analysis, island biogeography, meta-communities, climate change, and neutral theory. We will also examine and discuss the characteristics that make successful research ecologists and research programs. The class will be primarily driven by student discussion and presentations, and is aimed primarily at graduate students and advanced undergraduates.

subject: ES
course_name: ADV TPC:POLITICAL ECOLOGY: Land Use Agreements and First Nations Stewardship
additional_information: This class will be a practical exploration of what it takes to build land use agreements between First Nations, settler governments and stakeholders in British Columbia today. We will explore the interests of the different parties, the values and relationships and look at how ecology, economics, First Nations government-to-government decision making and the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous People (UNDRIP) influence how agreements are developed. With a focus on British Columbia and the role of multi stakeholder agreements including the Great Bear Rainforest, we will examine how First Nations are playing a leading role in re-imagining land stewardship. We will look at some of the key elements that make a successful agreement: First Nations decision making, old growth protection, carbon offsets, conservation financing, environmental monitoring, eco-tourism, and green energy. We will go beyond media soundbites to better appreciate the complex relationships, values and interests driving change.

subject: ES
course_name: ADV TPC:POLITICAL ECOLOGY: Radical Responses to the Climate Crisis
additional_information: What if catastrophe is something unfolding here and now, rather than something coming in the future? This course explores a range of responses to the catastrophe in which we live today: not just a catastrophe of climate instability and COVID-19; but also of isolation, extraction, depression, exploitation, hierarchy, debt, violence, boredom, and anxiety. This class foregrounds perspectives that seek to turn away fromâor move beyondâdominant approaches to social and political change, including protest, institutional reform, and individual ethics. While we will explore some critiques of these dominant tendencies, the focus will be on other ways of working together to transform the conditions under which we live, including direct action, mutual aid, counter-institutions, desertion, subsistence, and autonomy.

subject: ART
course_name: SPECIAL STUDIES: Research-Creation in Visual Arts
additional_information: Research-creation is an approach to scholarly work and creative practice that results in artwork made from deep engagement with a topic you research and then generate art from. This research could be personal, political, archival, community-based, scientific and/or historical. In this course, students will be challenged to create work in any medium as they respond to a series of research prompts, from digging into the personal archive (family photos, cultural practices, memorabilia) to the museum collection (who/how/why was it made, and why has it been preserved?) to society's most troubling issues (racism, climate change, capitalism, colonization). In this course we will study research-creation, learn from leading practitioners, and develop our own research-creation practices. Coursework will involve reading and in class discussion, research and research-creation with artistic outcomes.

subject: ANTH
course_name: EXPLORING ANTHROPOLOGY: Archaeology & Transformative Events In The Human Past
additional_information: Who were the earliest ancestors of humans and how did they live millions of years ago? When did people first arrive in North America and how did they get here? Why do some societies become states while other remain egalitarian? This course traces the trajectory of the ancient human past, beginning in the Paleolithic period, with anatomically modern humans and hunter-gatherers, and ending in the emergence of complex state and non-state societies. We will cover major transformative events in the story of human culture and society, such as the origins of agriculture and the development of urban life. Archaeological case studies will span the Old World and New World, including the Middle East, Mesopotamia, Western Europe, Mesoamerica, and the Northwest Coast.

subject: ANTH
course_name: ARCHAEOLOGY: Cultural Resource Management and the Practice of Archaeology
additional_information: This course surveys the origins and contemporary practice of archaeology in the public context, exploring the role that archaeology plays in the management of cultural heritage at the provincial, national, and international levels. Topics and case studies will include Canadian and international heritage legislation and policy, professional ethics, and the social relevance of cultural heritage, while also examining the intersection of archaeology and land use planning, development, and Indigenous rights. In the process, students will learn how and why archaeological overview assessments, impact assessments, mitigation studies, and site damage assessments are undertaken. Pre-req: 2nd year standing

subject: ANTH
additional_information: This course is fully online with one synchronous session each week. ANTH250 recommended, but not required. This undergraduate course, suitable for both majors and non-majors, will outline Neandertal biology, behavior, and current debates over the place of the Neandertals in human evolution. The main goal of the course is an up to date understanding about who the Neandertals were, and how they lived, through the examination of paleontological, archaeological, and molecular data. What did they look like? What did they eat? What sort of tools did they make? Were they our ancestors or not? Whatâs this I hear about a cave bear cult? As we evaluate the available evidence (and its limitations), we will also investigate the history of scientific and popular thought about Neandertals, and how it has reflected changes in broader societal attitudes over time. The course will include in-class, hands-on laboratory activities and open discussions. The reading list will range from selected journal articles to excerpts from popular literature like Clan of the Cave Bear.

subject: ANTH
course_name: SEMINAR IN ARCHAEOLOGY: (In)Visibile Histories: Heritage, Politics, And Memory
additional_information: What do Coachella music festival attendees, the Nefertiti Bust, and the Canadian Rocky Mountain Parks have in common? All three invoke heritage to convey messages and further agendas, whether it be through hipster headdresses, ancient artifacts, or as a representation of major geological and evolutionary processes in Earthâs history. In this course, we will explore the different kinds of heritage, including natural, cultural, and mixed, as well as tangible and intangible forms, interrogating its promotion, erasure, and manipulation from anthropological and archaeological perspectives. The course will also examine existing frameworks for the protection of heritage.

subject: ANTH
course_name: SEMINAR: CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY: Race, Racism and Anthropology
additional_information: Begins by taking a historical lens to examine how early anthropologists approached the study of race.  Examines the work of anthropologists who have challenged racist viewpoints in the discipline. Explores contemporary anthropological research and fieldwork involving notions of race and racism by scholars from diverse backgrounds. Engages students in learning how they themselves can actively engage in anti-racist thought and practice in an anthropological context. NOTE: This is an online synchronous seminar course for Spring 2025 meeting via Zoom.

subject: ANTH
additional_information: An introduction to the genre of graphic novels with emphasis on creative methodologies in ethnographic research. Designed to include students from any disciplinary background who may not have experience in the arts. Students will develop technical skills and learn approaches to creating graphic novels in research contexts. Through applied arts-based approaches to inquiry students will learn to read, and critically engage, and create their own graphic novel story.

subject: ANTH
course_name: EXPLORING ANTHROPOLOGY: Spirituality, Religion, Eco-Ethics, and the Other-Than-Human World
additional_information: Surveys the influence metaphysical, spiritual, and religious beliefs and practices have had upon humanity's interactions with, and understandings of, the other-than-human world. A consideration of the contributions that religious ethics can make to our reflection on specific environmental issues.

subject: ANTH
course_name: EXPLORING ANTHROPOLOGY: Race, Culture, and Power
additional_information: Provides an introduction to the discipline of anthropology's role in framing notions of race and includes an examination of: (1) how race is intertwined with ideologies of culture and power, (2) anthropological critiques and challenges to the concept of race, and (3) how race, culture, and power shape everyday life in contemporary societies.Â NOTE: This online course is a combination of synchronous and asynchronous teaching and learning in the Fall 2024. We will meet via zoom on Mondays for synchronous lecture sessions and Thursdays will be the asynchronous portion of the course.

subject: ANTH
additional_information: Explores many forms of human travel, from tourism to migration to pilgrimage, through the lens of anthropology.  Considers social and cultural meanings of travel, interrogates the âEat Pray Loveâ narrative around finding oneself in a foreign country, and examines how power influences how people move across space.

subject: ANTH
additional_information: What can archaeology tell us about the vices of past peoples, cultures and societies? This course will be a survey of case studies from a wide-ranging selection of regions and time periods, organized thematically around different so-called wicked behaviours. Rather than focus on the heroes of the past, this course will highlight the material remains of people behaving badly and engaging in deviant activities. Topics will include psychedelic drug use, cannibalism, prostitution, and the smuggling of illicit contraband, among others. Along the way, we will question whether these individuals are truly the villains of the past or if it is our own misconceptions that make them appear so.

subject: ANTH
course_name: BIOLOGICAL ANTHROPOLOGY: Evolution and Human Diversity
additional_information: This course will be offered fully online and blended (a mix of "real-time" and asynchronous sessions).  The story of our evolution and prevailing theories explaining how and why it proceeded are famously contentious. This three-field-oriented course (encompassing archaeological, cultural, and biological anthropological perspectives) is organized as a series of âcapsulesâ investigating specific contemporary and historical controversies in human evolution, and using these capsules to introduce and elaborate upon basic anthropological principles. Pre-req: One of ANTH100, ANTH240, ANTH250, BIOL184 or permission of the department.

subject: ANTH
additional_information: Arctic is home to unique ecosystems with fragile biodiversity as well as reach cultures celebrated by Indigenous Peoples and local communities. The goal of this course is to offer general introduction into the contemporary issues of the Circumpolar North with primary focus on Arctic Indigenous Peoples, Arctic knowledge systems, environmental stewardship, and policies.  Course discussions, readings, and assignments are aimed to enhance the understanding of what Arctic is today and what is the place of human in the Arctic.

subject: ANTH
course_name: SEMINAR:CULTURAL ANTHROPOLOGY: Anthropology of the Body
additional_information: Anthropology of the Body is intended to disrupt, provoke, and enrich how we think about bodies and how we construct âthe bodyâ. While we tend of think of bodies as natural and âtaken for grantedâ, this course will examine how bodies are culturally, historically,  politically, and economically constructed.

subject: CS
course_name: TOPICS IN CANADIAN STUDIES: A Cultural Study of Poverty and Homelessness
additional_information: Explores the homelessness crisis through the lens of Canadian social policy formulation focusing on connections between past policy decisions and current problems. Evaluates policy solutions and contextualizes the Canadian experience with that of other jurisdictions. Themes include mental illness and addiction; racial, gender and age determinants of poverty and homelessness past and present; Indigenous homelessness; neoliberalism; inequality and the politics of defining and measuring poverty.

subject: CE
additional_information: APPLICATION PROCESS: Permission to register in this course is by application. To apply, please send an email to soscassist@uvic.ca including your student number, major, resume or CV, term you are applying for, and a 2-3 paragraph response to the following question: "What is your motivation to take this community-engaged learning course? Please share an experience or two that have prepared you for this type of learning experience." OFF-CAMPUS component: This course includes a placement consisting of a minimum of 40 hours of unpaid work with a community organization or on a community project. Placement schedules are co-created between students and community, with support from staff and faculty. While this does not imply more overall time dedication to this course, students should consider if their schedule can accommodate community experience.

subject: CS
course_name: Issues and Ideas in Canadian Environmentalism

subject: CS
course_name: TOPICS IN CANADIAN STUDIES: How to Change the World: Canadian Grassroots Organizations
additional_information: Grassroots community organizations are at the heart of much social, environmental and economic change in Canada. They have historically been the âsmall groups of committed citizensâ that âchange the worldâ for the better. This course explores the history, achievements and possibilities inherent in grassroots organizations in Canada, using provocative examples from across the country  but with a focus on British Columbia movements. The course will also include a community-engaged component, offering opportunity for students to engage with a local community organization, pairing their class learning on the theory, practice and history of grassroots social and environmental justice movements with on-the-ground experience.

subject: COM
course_name: ADVANCED MANAGEMENT TOPICS: Managing for Sustainability: Concepts, Tools and Practices
additional_information: Open to non-business students via request for registration form starting on August 1: https://www.uvic.ca/gustavson/undergraduate/minor/index.php. How to Live and Work Sustainably on a Finite Planet: Responsible Management and Circular Economy Transformation. This course will equip you with the conceptual and technical tools to manage your organization in a way that addresses economic, environmental and social goals. You will learn how to apply the principles and practices of circular economy, a system that minimizes waste and maximizes value, to various industries such as speciality foods, construction, performance wear and retail. Through simulations, case discussions, and team learning activities, you will gain an action-oriented understanding of the business systems and strategies that enable sustainable development. This exciting and relevant course aims to prepare you for the challenges and opportunities of working and living sustainably on a finite planet.

subject: COM
course_name: ADVANCED MANAGEMENT TOPICS: Strategies for Emerging Markets
additional_information: This course derives its logic from the growing significance of emerging markets and seeks to develop concepts and tools for designing and implementing effective competitive strategies to operate and win in these markets. It will also explore the rapid changes that these markets are currently undergoing and their implications for global strategy. The course will build on the concepts and issues raised in the core competitive strategy course. Open to non-business students via request for registration form starting on August 1: https://www.uvic.ca/gustavson/undergraduate/minor/index.php.

subject: COM
course_name: ADVANCED MANAGEMENT TOPICS: Applied Data Analysis for Business
additional_information: Open to non-business students via request for registration form starting on August 1: https://www.uvic.ca/gustavson/undergraduate/minor/index.php This course introduces students to the basic concepts, techniques, uses, and limitations of modern data analysis tools and machine learning in an applied business context. Topics may include data visualization, regression, decision trees, cluster analysis, association rule mining, text/web mining, and artificial neural networks. In addition, we will develop an understanding of Generative AI prompt engineering to write code to implement these tools. This course will emphasize the application of data analysis, concepts, and techniques, rather than theoretical foundations. No knowledge is assumed, and no coding background is required.

subject: COM
course_name: ADVANCED MANAGEMENT TOPICS: How to Build an App Startup
instructor: Margaret-Anne Darragh  Storey (P), Claudia G  Smith
additional_information: Open to non-business students via request for registration form starting on August 1: https://www.uvic.ca/gustavson/undergraduate/minor/index.php. This applied course will be cross-listed with a 4th year computer science course. Over the term, interdisciplinary teams of business and computer science students will create new applications to leverage identified market problems/opportunities. Business students will be introduced to some key principals in software design and UIX/UX but will not be responsible for programming (unless there is an interest to pursue this area). By the end of the term, the goal is to have a market-ready app venture ready for launch, which students can then choose to pursue further. Students will have an opportunity to work with a group of app/software entrepreneurs as mentors throughout the term.

subject: COM
course_name: ADVANCED MANAGEMENT TOPICS: International Organizations in a Global World
additional_information: This course, 'International organizations in a global world ', will equip you with a deeper understanding of how international organizations like the United Nations, World Bank, and World Trade Organization, address global (business) issues. Through case studies, discussions, and critical analysis, you will gain insights into how these organizations shape international relations and influence the global political and economic landscape.

subject: CE
additional_information: APPLICATION PROCESS: Permission to register in this course is by application. To apply, please send an email to soscassist@uvic.ca including your student number, major, resume or CV, term you are applying for, and a 2-3 paragraph response to the following question: "What is your motivation to take this community-engaged learning course? Please share an experience or two that have prepared you for this type of learning experience." OFF-CAMPUS component: This course includes a placement consisting of a minimum of 40 hours of unpaid work with a community organization or on a community project. Placement schedules are co-created between students and community, with support from staff and faculty. While this does not imply more overall time dedication to this course, students should consider if their schedule can accommodate community experience.

subject: NURS
course_name: SPECIAL TOPICS: Nursing in Primary Health Care
additional_information: Students examine the theoretical and conceptual foundations of primary health care nursing practice. They explore nursesâ role and scope in team-based primary health care contexts. Students advance their knowledge in comprehensive and focused individual health assessment across the life course, decision-making and priority setting in primary health care contexts, chronic disease management, client teaching, and health-promoting and equity-oriented practices with diverse populations.

subject: EOS
additional_information: An overview of natural hazards including earthquakes, volcanoes, tsunami, landslides, flooding, extreme weather, wildfires and space hazards. Particular attention is given to hazards affecting southwestern British Columbia, hazards related to climate change, and important historic natural disasters. This is an introductory-level course that does not require a science/math background.

subject: PSYC
course_name: ADV SPCL TPCS:PSYC: Psychology for Instruction
additional_information: Psychological science has much to contribute to enhancing teaching and learning across a range of educational contexts. Drawing on contemporary research, this course will explore evidenced-based principles from psychology that inform the design of effective and responsive learning environments. The course will be of interest to students who are interested in (a) applying psychological science to instructional design or assessment, (b) developing instructional tools and interventions, (c ) pursuing careers related to education or instructional design, or (d) contributing to research in the psychology of education. This is a good course for future teaching assistants.
